Functional Requirements.name: Functional Requirements
Functional Requirements.description: Requirements that specify what the system should do

frameworks.name: IEEE 830 Standard
frameworks.definition: Functional requirements define the fundamental actions that must take place in the software in accepting and processing the inputs and in processing and generating the outputs
characteristics: Describes what the system should do
Specifies functions that a system must perform
Focuses on user tasks and goals
frameworks.citation: IEEE (1998). IEEE Recommended Practice for Software Requirements Specifications. IEEE Std 830-1998

frameworks.name: Sommerville's Software Engineering
frameworks.definition: Functional requirements are statements of services the system should provide, how the system should react to particular inputs, and how the system should behave in particular situations
characteristics: May state what the system should not do
frameworks.citation: Ian Sommerville (2016). Software Engineering. Pearson Education

Non-Functional Requirements.name: Non-Functional Requirements
Non-Functional Requirements.description: Requirements that specify how the system should behave or qualities it should have

Performance.name: Performance
Performance.description: System performance characteristics like speed, throughput, response time

frameworks.name: NFR Framework
frameworks.definition: Performance refers to the speed of operation of a system. It includes throughput (number of transactions processed per unit time) and response time (time elapsed between request and response)
characteristics: Can be measured in various units (transactions/sec, milliseconds, etc.)
Often has trade-offs with other NFRs
frameworks.citation: Lawrence Chung, Brian Nixon, Eric Yu et al. (2000). Non-Functional Requirements in Software Engineering. Kluwer Academic Publishers
examples: The system shall process 1000 transactions per second
Response time shall be less than 2 seconds for 95% of queries

frameworks.name: ISO/IEC 25010 Quality Model
frameworks.definition: Performance efficiency: The performance relative to the amount of resources used under stated conditions. Includes time behavior, resource utilization, and capacity
characteristics: Time behavior: Response and processing times and throughput rates
Resource utilization: Amounts and types of resources used
Capacity: Maximum limits of a product or system parameter
frameworks.citation: ISO/IEC (2011). Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE). ISO/IEC 25010:2011

frameworks.name: Roman's FURPS+ Model
frameworks.definition: Performance requirements specify numerical values for measurable variables such as response time, throughput, capacity, and resource usage
frameworks.citation: Glinz Roman (1987). The FURPS+ System for Classifying Software Requirements. HP Software Engineering Productivity Conference

Security.name: Security
Security.description: Protection against unauthorized access and data breaches

frameworks.name: NFR Framework
frameworks.definition: Security refers to the system's ability to protect information and resources from unauthorized access and use. It includes confidentiality, integrity, availability, and accountability
frameworks.citation: Lawrence Chung, Brian Nixon, Eric Yu et al. (2000). Non-Functional Requirements in Software Engineering. Kluwer Academic Publishers
examples: User passwords must be encrypted using AES-256
System shall log all access attempts

frameworks.name: ISO/IEC 25010 Quality Model
frameworks.definition: Security: Degree to which a product or system protects information and data so that persons or other products or systems have the degree of data access appropriate to their types and levels of authorization
characteristics: Confidentiality: Data accessible only to authorized users
Integrity: Prevention of unauthorized data modification
Non-repudiation: Actions can be proven to have taken place
Accountability: Entity actions can be traced uniquely
Authenticity: Identity of a subject or resource can be proved
frameworks.citation: ISO/IEC (2011). Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE). ISO/IEC 25010:2011

frameworks.name: Common Criteria (ISO/IEC 15408)
frameworks.definition: Security functional requirements describe the security behavior of a TOE (Target of Evaluation). They are organized into classes, families, and components covering various security functions
frameworks.citation: ISO/IEC (2017). Information technology — Security techniques — Evaluation criteria for IT security. ISO/IEC 15408:2017

Usability.name: Usability
Usability.description: Ease of use and user experience aspects

frameworks.name: Nielsen's Usability Heuristics
frameworks.definition: Usability is a quality attribute that assesses how easy user interfaces are to use. It includes learnability, efficiency, memorability, errors, and satisfaction
characteristics: Learnability: How easy for first-time users
frameworks.citation: Jakob Nielsen (1994). Usability Engineering. Morgan Kaufmann

frameworks.name: ISO 9241-11 Usability
frameworks.definition: Usability: Extent to which a system, product or service can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use
characteristics: Effectiveness: Accuracy and completeness of goals achieved
Efficiency: Resources expended in relation to results
frameworks.citation: ISO (2018). Ergonomics of human-system interaction — Part 11: Usability: Definitions and concepts. ISO 9241-11:2018

Reliability.name: Reliability
Reliability.description: System dependability, availability, and fault tolerance

Portability.name: Portability
Portability.description: Ability to work in different environments

Compatibility.name: Compatibility
Compatibility.description: Ability to work with other systems

Mixed Requirements.name: Mixed Requirements
Mixed Requirements.description: Requirements that contain both functional and non-functional aspects

frameworks.name: Thesis Definition (Based on NFR Framework)
frameworks.definition: A mixed requirement is a single requirement statement that explicitly contains both functional aspects (what the system should do) and non-functional aspects (quality attributes or constraints on how the system should do it)
characteristics: Contains explicit quality attribute or constraint
Cannot be cleanly separated without losing meaning
examples: The system shall process login requests and authenticate users within 2 seconds
The system shall encrypt all data transmissions using AES-256 when sending patient records
The application shall display search results sorted by relevance with response time under 1 second

frameworks.name: Thesis Custom Framework
frameworks.definition: Requirements that exhibit both functional behavior and quality constraints in a single statement, identified through dual-aspect analysis
characteristics: Cannot be decomposed without losing semantic meaning
examples: The system shall process and validate user input within 100ms
The application shall securely store and encrypt sensitive data
